20. In terms of solutions, I might encourage universities, government funding agencies, & philanthropies to consider the creation of multidisciplinary/ hybrid institutes or think tanks which can support breakthrough work as their core mission.

19. But when all is said and done, there is little doubt in my mind that more & more of the university has become a place to conduct follow-on or confirmatory as opposed to breakthrough or exploratory research.
18. They were drawn to tech startups because they wanted to see their creations make it into the world ...

17. One thing I recall from the interviews I did two decades ago for Rise of the Creative Class is that many of the young computer scientists & engineers I spoke with said publishing papers or even registering patents was not enough ...

16. If I had to fathom a guess or hypothesis I would say that we may be seeing a shift in breakthrough research out of universities per se and into these kinds of more specialized instituted and to startups.

15.  I fully believe the breakthrough work continues to happen. But that is happens in a relatively small number of spaces that value it - a few uber elite universities like Harvard MIT, CMU, specialized institutes, & some startups/companies.
14. I have seen many of the most promising minds in my fields - urbanism, economics, social science, many present here on twitter - choose to work outside of academia for these reasons.

13. I have been told time and time again over the course of my career to stop working on big issues, to focus on well-defined problems, stop working on books, & work instead on narrowly defined journal articles. (And this is how are loads & promotions are defined).
12. "What I learned as a Dean is that most academics work incredibly hard on unbelievably small bore problems."
11. As a former dean who came from outside the university once told me: "I used to think academics took lots & lots of time to ponder huge intellectual challenges" ...
10. There is a huge bias in the university - or at least in most places - against exploratory research and in favor of confirmatory research.

9. Of course we know that typical grant making organizations also favor work that builds on prior research. So it is much harder to attract funding for breakthrough work which by its nature is unproven.

8. And this is not just junior faculty., Senior faculty are rewarded more by publishing & more frequently in established disciplinary journals. If you have to publish frequently, it reduces the likelihood of even considering big problems.
7. Faculty are incentivized to publish more & more frequently in disciplanary journals. It is much easier to publish follow-on kinds of work in these journals than to publish breakthrough research.
6. University incentives for faculty, especially at the not-very-best places have evolved to dissuade breakthrough or disruptive work.

5. But it is also clear to me as the pool of research has increased, especially in universities, the incentives have evolved away from breakthrough science. I have seen this over the course of my own career which began in the mid-1980s.
4. My sense is that there is disruptive work going on in some places like MIT, CMU, certain institutes, startups, but it is smaller relative to the larger pool of papers and patents.

3. ""We are not saying [the difference reflects] the quality of the work" ...The difference is that the more recent papers describe consolidating rather than disruptive inventions." https://t.co/3y4K0b2bnu

2. First off, as the authors describe there is a basic numbers issue at work: "because the number of research papers overall has skyrocketed ...while the number of disrupted papers has stayed roughly constant, the fraction of all papers that are disruptive has declined." ...

@evan7257 Quick question. I have now read the study several times. Perhaps this disruptive elements has switched from university to industry/startups. But I cannot discern if it includes publications and patents from non-university sources ...
@evan7257 Not that I know of. Maybe at MIT or CMU? We also know that great breakthroughs require people from different disciplines - outside the field - coming together.

@evan7257 My hunch is that folks who want to do disruptive research leave the University. They will find another kind of place where they can marshall resources and get support to do this kind of work. It’s harder and harder to do this in a university.

@evan7257 Thank you. I had basically the same reaction when reading the study. And I know the incentives I get is a faculty member, or distinctly against any sort of breakthrough. Publish in mainstream journals publish a lot. Do basically confirmatory research. Avoid exploratory research.

30. Other cities should use this example to develop rebuilding strategies of their own.

29. NYC faces considerable headwinds. But I always bet long on what has proven to be America's and the world's most economically resilient city, able to reinvent itself time and time again over the past century and more.
28. The good news is that the report & initiiative appear to have the support of the governor anbd the state; the mayor and the city; & the private and civic sectors.
27. A city where more affordable housing is built, where offices are converted into housing, & where inclusivity becomes a central piece of the strategy & policy mix.
26. One where employment is spread across the boros closet to where people live, and Manhattan's office hubs transform into more mixed-use, resident-friendly commmunities.
25. The report outlines an expansion & yet practical approach to rebuilding NY and its downtowns as a more mixed use, vibrant, affordable & inclusive place.

5. The gap in labor force participation between parents and non-parents widened to more than 5 percent during the pandemic. Giving all New Yorkers access to childcare will help all families realize their earning potential, and potentially increase economic output by $23 billion.

24. Housing affordability is key. Zoning reforms, tax incentives, office building conversions or replacements can all dramatically increase the stock of affordable housing. FAR restrictions on density should be lifted.
23. Offshore wind is a huge opportunity that the city is just beginning to embrace.

22. The city should leverage green technology to  catalyze the jobs of the future. It can enlist its growing startup community to develop smart technologies for building and property management, mobility, infrastructure, and sustainability.
21. Sustainability is another key theme. New York can leverage green technologies and the growth of e-commerce to capture and catalyze the jobs of the future.
20.  90 percent of the 26,000 businesses that closed during the pandemic had less than 10 employees; black-owned businesses were twice as likely to close as white-owned businesses.
19. Inclusion is a central theme. Catalyzing inclusive growth is a huge challenge, given the yawning disparities that exist within the city.
18. The city currently leases 22 million square feet of commercial space. Some of it can be used to anchor new commercial developments. City libraries can become co-working spaces for remote workers

17. Investing in employment hubs across all five boroughs will allow workers to stay closer to home, and bring New York closer to the ideal of the 15-minute city, where everyone can work, go to school, and shop within 15 minutes of their homes
16. One of the most important recommendations is to decentralize employment centers to the outer boros while revitalizing  & enlivening Manhattan's two business districts

15. Redesigning the bus network, upgrading fare collections so riders can use the Long Island Railroad and the MTA for local trips, expanding bikeway infrastructure, and reducing car traffic with congestion pricing will all make a difference.

14. 8 million people rode public transit in New York before the pandemic. Ridership has returned to about 70% t of its previous level (60% in the subways). Weekday bus ridership is about 2/3s what it was. More people would use the system if it was faster and more reliable.
13. Developing a centralized, city-wide approach to waste containerization will improve quality of life in every neighborhood, reducing dirt, smells, and rats.

12. Investments in public spaces in Midtown & downtown business districts can help attract foot traffic, and with it, new retail & food service providers. Pop up stores, galleries, street concerts, & investments in culture will also give people reasons to visit business districts

11. Loosening the very stringent regulations that make it so onerous and expensive to convert office buildings to residents provides the opportunity to add affordable housing in neighborhoods with big economic opportunities
10. By adding flexibility to zoning regulations, business districts can evolve more rapidly into dynamic, mixed-use neighborhoods that draw not just workers, but tourists and full-time residents.
9. "To truly establish New York as the world’s best place to work,” the report says, “We need to make New York the best place, period.”
8. The report's 40 initiatives support three goals: reimagining New York’s business districts as 24/7 destinations; making it easier to get around; and generating inclusive, future-focused growth.

7. 24 percent of city households spend more than half their income on housing. Childcare is unaffordable for 93 percent of households. Black and Hispanic New Yorkers have twice the poverty rate and half the median household incomes of white New Yorkers.

6. In January, 2020, New York City had 8.8 million people and 4.7 million jobs, clocking the lowest unemployment rate in its history. But there were growing signs that its deep inequalities—in income, opportunity, education, and access to transportation—were unsustainable.

5. The report reinforces the point (that I have been making since the onset of the pandemic) that COVID is not so much the fundamental disruptor of cities urban life as an accelerator of existing trends already well underway.

4. The scopes the problem & outlines 40 initiatives to repurpose and restore the city’s business districts, improve quality of life issues from crime to dirty garbage-strewn streets & rats, invest in mass transportation, and grow the city’s housing supply in an inclusive way.
3. I think it is a terrific report which lays out the key issues in creating more economic successful, mixed-use, people-oriented and inclusive cities & downtowns.

17. Governments can also take steps to provide more direct assistance to lower-income creators, members of minority groups, and residents of distressed neighborhoods and communities. The public and non-profit sectors can provide scholarships for less-advantaged creators.
16. Community colleges can develop training programs to help creators build more sustainable enterprises with predictable revenue streams.

15. Federal, state, and local governments can identify, organize, and support clusters of creators, much like their long-standing efforts to support high-tech and arts clusters. They can aid in the development of shared benefit pools for health and other kinds of insurance.

14.  They can identify peer communities and establish Creator Schools where creators can learn from each other. They must also redouble their efforts to ensure that creators, especially women & people of color, are better protected from harassment.

13.A key challenge  is to create a larger and more sustainable “middle class” of Creators. Digital platforms can promote less-established creators by tweaking their algorithms and give creators more exposure to data and analytics.
12. A considerable share are social and political activists, who are principally motivated by the desire to serve causes larger than themselves and have social and political impact.

11. yet, despite what is  said about creators’ frenetic pursuit of fame and fortune, most are more intrinsically motivated. They seek to follow their passions and work on ideas, activities, and projects that give them a sense of purpose.

10. Just1.4% of creators make more than $1 million per year; and another 1.5% make between $500,000 and $1 million. Fully two-thirds of creators earn less than $25,000 annually, and more than a quarter earn less than $1,000.
9. While the Creator Economy democratizes content creation to some degree, its financial rewards resemble the superstar/ winner-take-all pattern of traditional media/celebrity industries.

8. This is not to imply that talent holds all the cards: Traditional gatekeepers still wield a lot of power, as do the platforms themselves, whose algorithms weigh heavily in what will and won’t go viral.

7. The rise of the broader Creative Economy is accelerating the gradual shift in "power" from large firms and gatekeepers to talent - it create additional porosity that enables more diverse talent to do an end around these gatekeepers.

6. Geographically speaking, just 3 city-regions—the San Francisco, Bay Area, Los Angeles, and New York—account for nearly 2/3s of all global venture capital investment in the Creator Economy. But, VC investment in Creator Economy startups can be found in 65 global cities.
5. he overall size of the Creator Economy was pegged to be more than $100 billion; and almost $15 billion in venture capital has been invested in some 300 Creator Economy startups since 2021.

4. More than 85 million Americans and more than 300 million people across nine large nations were estimated to post their creative content online in 2022. Roughly 17 million creators were found to actually earn revenue on nine major digital platforms as of 2017.

3. While creators are often thought of as merely digital influencers, they’re better understood as anyone who makes and publishes unique content online, whether that’s videos, films, art, music, designs, text, games, or any other media that audiences can access.
2. I argue that the recent rise of online creators and the Creator Economy is the digital manifestation of the rise of creativity as a key element in our economy, society, and everyday lives.

36. More sustainable economic prosperity
turns on unleashing the creative potential of as many people as possible. A stronger Creator Economy and larger Creator middle class is essential to making
that happen.
35. As the report details, new policies and institutions to bolster the Creator middle class are important both to bolster the Creator Economy and to strengthen the economy and society more broadly.

34. Government must also take steps to provide more direct assistance to lower-income Creators, members of minority groups, and residents of distressed 
neighborhoods and communities. The public and non-profit sectors can provide scholarships for less-advantaged Creators.
33.  Local community colleges and universities can develop training programs to assist Creators in generating more stable and predictable revenue streams and building more sustainable enterprises.
32. Government can aid in the development of shared benefit pools for health and other kinds of insurance.

31.  Federal, state, and local governments can help identify, organize, and support clusters or networks of Creators, similar to their long-standing efforts to
support high-tech and arts clusters.
30. Public policy must also help support Creators, bolster the Creator Economy, and ensure Creators are protected from discrimination and harassment.
29. It is paramount that platforms redouble their efforts to ensure that Creators, especially women and people of color, are better protected from harassment.
29.Platforms can identify peer communities of Creators that can share their experiences and identify best practices and establish Creator Schools where Creators can share and learn from one

28. They can give Creators more exposure to
data dashboards and help them better understand how to use data analytics to improve their effectiveness.
27.   Platforms can provide resources & training to help less-established Creators to improve their engagement, monetization, and growth opportunities.
26. Digital platforms can promote less-established Creators by tweaking their algorithms to introduce more discovery into what audiences see.
25. The report outlines key strategies platforms, technology & media companies & government at all levels can undertake for building a more sustainable Creator Middle Class.

24. Not everyone can or should expect to get rich as an online Creator or influencer, but with support from platforms and the government, many more can earn substantial livelihoods from their creative production
than they do today.
23. Going forward, the key challenge for the Creator Economy is to create a larger and more sustainable “middle class” of Creators who earn a reasonable living.

22. Many are devoted hobbyists who are pursuing creative
activities they are deeply passionate about. A growing number are social and political activists, who are principally motivated by the desire to serve causes bigger than themselves and have social and political impact.

21. The vast majority of Creators are motivated by the ability to work on projects they are passionate about and give them a sense of meaning and purpose; that enable them to connect with like-minded others; and allow them more control over their schedules.

20. But money, fame, and audience size are far from the only metrics for Creator success. Our interviews with Creators and our review of various surveys of them show that Creators derive intrinsic satisfaction from their work.

20. While a small percentage of superstar creators earn millions from their on-line content, fully two-thirds of them earn less than $25,000 annually, and more than a quarter earn less than $1,000, according to recent studies.

19. Even content creation has been democratized to a degree, the earnings that come from it remain highly concentrated, reflecting the long-standing
“winner-take-all” dynamic of talent-based and celebrity-driven industries.

18. Digital technologies enable Creators to bypass traditional institutional gatekeepers in the movie, music, publishing, & broadcasting industries. This does not mean that talent holds all the cards. Large corporate gatekeepers & digital platforms remain powerful.

17. The rise of digitally based Creators and the Creator Economy is accelerating an ongoing shift in the balance of power from large corporations and cultural and artistic gatekeepers to talent brought on the rise of creativity as a productive force and economic engine.

16. While Los Angeles and New York are the leading U.S. locations for successful Creators, the vast majority of digital Creators and of Creatives more broadly are spread across other places across the globe.

15.  Just three city-regions—the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, and New York—account
for nearly two-thirds of all global venture capital investment in Creator Economy startups. But such startups can also be found in more than 65 other
cities around the world.

14. The report digs into the geography of Creators & the Creator Economy. At the same time that Creators can and do literally work from anywhere, key elements of the Creator Economy are geographically clustered.
13. The overall size of the size of the Creator Economy was estimated to be more than $100 billion as of 2020.

12. Digital Creators number more than 300 million people across nine large nations, including more than 85 million Americans. Roughly 17 million American Creators earned money by selling their digital content as of 2017. 2020, according to recent estimates.
11. The more recent rise of Digital Creators & the Creator Economy is an outgrowth of this. And both are large & growing.
10. The Creative Class has grown from around 10 or 15 percent of the U.S. workforce in 1980 to more than 40 or 50 percent in leading cities and nations today.

9. Some 60 million Americans belong to the Creative Class, up from less than 40 million two decades, meaning they are directly employed and paid to work with their creativity in fields spanning arts and culture; science and innovation; and the knowledge-based professions.
8. The rise of creativity as a factor of production is not just reshaping the economy per se, but the underlying class structure of society.

7. The Creator Economy is the broader economic and social infrastructure that enables the work of Creators. It comprises the technological and economic ecosystem in which Creators do their work and engage their audiences, including digital platforms, startup companies, and more.
6. We define Creators as those who use digital technology to make and publish unique creative content, whether in the form of video, film, art, music, design, text, games, or any other media.
5. But over the past several decades, knowledge, intelligence, and creativity have become essential engines of innovation and economic growth.

4. The Creator Economy is the digital manifestation of the rise of creativity as a key element in our economy, society, and everyday lives. For most of human history, societies were organized around the exploitation of natural resources via physical labor.
3. Thanks are due the entire @Creative_Class team particularly @ranaflorida, @UrbanAdler, @ArthurGoldwag and Taner Osman.

15. Even as traditional offices decline, this bodes well for the shift from the mono-functional Central Business Districts of yesterday to the diverse, mixed-used Central Connectivity Districts of tomorrow ...
14. This suggests that cities & innovative organizations should make more use of these kinds of organizational spaces in the future.

13. And of course the study suggests that co-working spaces & third places of all sorts where people from different organizations mix & mingle are more important that traditional office environments for innovation & for cities.

12. In a way, you can say that traditional offices were more mechanisms for massing & controlling professional & knowledge workers while cities are platforms for spurring interaction and innovation across creative endeavors.
11. Cities are essential platforms for this kind of interaction, that is much less likely to occur in traditional single company office environments and far less likely to occur on Zoom.

10. While this is a study of a single co-working space it shows the critical role played by density, diversity & face-to-face interaction & socialization in cities. It is this kind of interaction between people from different organizations that has long spurred innovation.
9. And the clincher: "Ultimately, startups that are embedded in environments that have neither too much nor too little diversity perform better, but only if they socialize."

8. "The main driver of the effect appears to be social interactions. While startups in close proximity are most likely to participate in social co-working space events together, knowledge spillovers are greatest between startups that socialize but are dissimilar."

7. "This effect is largest for startups within close proximity of each other and quickly decays: startups more than 20 meters apart on the same floor are indistinguishable from startups on different floors. The main driver of the effect appears to be social interactions."

5. As the WSJ summarizes: "knowledge spillovers were greatest between dissimilar startups that worked within 20 meters of each other. Working in such close range allowed for socialization, which in turn led to idea sharing" ...
4.The study examined a co-working space where new startups were located in close proximity on the same floor.
3. This study examines effect of proximity of people from different tech startups in a large co-working space. The WSJ story is here: https://t.co/uQSBvnU6tw

2. Ever since Jane Jacobs, economic geographers & urban economists have argued that it is more street-level interaction (as opposed to in-office interactions) among people from different firms or even different musical acts that spurs innovation.

9. All of this portends that workspaces will get better - pressure/ competition is arising for better, more human-scale, neighborhood-based workspace. Remote work will engender better physical workspaces. It's already happening ...

8. In my research for Rise of the Creative Class, people told me again & again, they wanted to work on great projects with great people in great spaces in great places. That has not changed. But they want those spaces closer to where they live.

7. These kinds of more spatially-rooted, neighborhood-based co-working spaces are already cropping up in big cities like London. Next step will be their movement into suburbs and rural areas. Here is one example: https://t.co/mOD1UWBJuM

6. What is more likely is that on top of the new digital technologies than enable remote work, we will begin to see a further, natural evolution to neighborhood-based work spaces or even remote work districts.

3. If anything the shift to remote work portends more and better work spaces. A shift that has been going on for a while, including everything from third places like coffee shops to co-working spaces.

9. The new reality of work involves working at multiple work sites – home, co-working space, central office. The lion's share of professional/ creative workers work this way now, and have been trending this way for awhile.

8. The new reality of work defies the convenient binary of work from home vs work from the office. I guess the term of art is **hybrid** (a term I do not love)... It involves working flexibly from multiple locations & is blurred & blended.

7. We boiled it down to a simple phrase: Knowledge workers/ the creative class wanted to work on great projects, with great people, in great SPACES, in great places.  The last 2 in particular were emphasized & I do not think the pandemic has changed that all too much.

21. Despite the many issues facing downtowns, things are going better than expected in the long run than anyone, including Fogelson, would have expected two decades ago.

20. Even though things seems bleak in some downtowns  currently, what actually seems to be happening is a ly reversal of the cycle of that separation of home and work and reknitting and reintegrating them in new and powerful and more humane ways.
19. What we are doing is actually reversing the cycle of that separation of home and work and re-knitting and reintegrating them in new and powerful and more humane ways.
18. Downtown is already in the throes of reinvention. In fact, that reinvention is much farther along than what Fogelson imagined might happen when he wrote the book.
17. What we are going through is not new. Nor is it the worst crisis downtown has faced. Look at a whole host of major urban centers in the 1970s and 1980s.
16. Fogelson was awfully pessimistic about the prospects for downtowns revival when he published the book in 2001. He could not anticipate what would happen in the past 20 years.
15. Downtown has been beset by challenges and crises almost from the start. And it has been in decline for half a century.
14. This is a constant theme - business and real estate interests organizing to save and revitalize downtown ... what is happening today is not new ...

13. In the wake of all of this downtown real estate and business interests began to organize to save and revitalize downtowns. This gave rise after the war to revitalization efforts like Pittsburgh Renaissance and urban renewal broadly speaking.

12. Some shopping too began to decentralize early on as early shopping centers cropped up in the suburbs. There were really worries about downtown even before the Great Depression, which obviously made things a lot worse.
11. Downtown was already becoming DEPOPULATED by the early 20th century as a result. And industry was already decentralizing and dispersing as well ...
10. The term central business district enters the lexicon i the early 1900s to identify these specialized downtown business and shopping areas.

9. Struggles over  height limits, increased congestion & the encroachment of factories into business, shopping & residential neighborhoods led to the rise of building and zoning codes in the early 20th century, which further accelerated the rise of specialized business districts.

8. Technologies like the street railway, the subway and the modern skyscraper (with elevators) accelerated this separation of work from home, and the rise of what we now know as "central business districts."
7. Olmstead saw this as a good thing, part of the "law of progress" that would lead to a cleaner, healthier, more orderly society.
6. Around this time, people like Frederick Law Olmstead began to point to the increasing separation of business and residences that was characteristic of the rising industrial society and economy.
5. By around the 1880s, these cities were increasingly divided into newer "uptown" residential areas, and "downtown" areas with factories, shops and early business districts.

4. The very term "downtown" appears to have emerged in the early to mid-19th century, as American cities like NY & Boston & Philadelphia grew and shops & rudimentary offices began to spin off into independent entities outside of the "home."
3. "Downtown" as we know it is a recent construction.   Bound up with the separation of work from home brought on by the industrial revolution.

2. The big takeaway is that downtown has been through much worse before, and what downtown is going through today is part of a long historical trajectory. Indeed, Fogelson was much more pessimistic about downtown's future in 2001 than what has transpired since.

16. So, to sum it all up, while the pandemic & remote work are thought to devastate the office markets & revenue bases of NY & San Fran, Austin's tax base is hit about as hard & Atlanta takes a bigger hit. Huh ..
15. And this ... "Our estimates of the revenue deficit, as compared to previous years, are between 5% and 7%, exceeding 8% in Austin, NYC, and SF. "

14. And this: "By contrast, cities in Texas and Florida, where state aid is low and property tax shares are high, will need to reevaluate their fundamental fiscal stance, which is based on no state income taxes."
13. This ... "Diversified revenue structures, with a major role for state aid, and in NYC’s case the local personal income tax, partially insulate both NYC and SF from the pandemic fiscal shock."
12. "Despite its strong economy, Austin, with 50% of all revenues from the property tax, faces revenue losses between 2% and 4%, similar to the forecasts for New York and San Francisco."
11. "Due to its high share of CI property in the property tax base and its relative dependence on the property tax, Atlanta has the largest revenue effect (-5.7%)."

10. The study: "Because the larger cities in our sample have more diversified revenue structures, while smaller cities like Austin and Miami are more dependent on the property tax, overall revenue effects are more even across cities than commercial property tax effects alone."

9. But here is the *thing* and its a big one, because of differences in the composition of city revenues the city with the biggest hit to revenues is Atlanta, with the hit to booming Austin being similar to NY or San Franciso.

8. The study finds about the impact on NYC commercial real estate prices is roughly equally divided between the COVID 19 recession and remote work, with the "stand-alone WFH effect on NY commercial property values range from 16% to 31%".

7. "NY and San Francisco are the most vulnerable of the 8 cities, with predicted commercial price drops ranging from 25% to 43%. Declines are somewhat smaller, but still significant in the other cities ..."
6. "The direct employment effects of the COVID-19 recession in 2020 on commercial real estate values are estimated at 6% on average, ranging from 1% in Austin to 13% in San Francisco."
5. In the 8 cities studied "commercial real estate accounts for an average of 37% of property taxes, ranging from 26% in LA to 56% in Atlanta."

4.The study note: "By combining data on employment, earnings, &  city fiscal structure with estimates of the potential decline in commercial real estate values, this research helps to pull back the curtain on the black box of the pandemic threat to cities and their finances."
3. Here is a cool graphic of the way they scope the issue: https://t.co/Bg30Q7m3IY

2. The study examines the fiscal impact of remote work on 8 cities, including 4 which are said to be vulnerable to remote work NY, San Fran, LA & Chicago, and 4 which are thought  to be gaining from remote work like Atlanta, Miami, Charlotte & Austin.

7. So now on top of a low inventory situation, you have more people who are locked in, even if they'd prefer to move. Seems like a pretty big issue to me ...

6. So what happens, and I am hearing this more and more, is people get locked in. They decide their best option, even if they'd like to move, is to stay where they are. The jump in carrying costs is too steep.
5. Take someone who has a nice house, mostly paid off, and they'd like to move. If essentially the same or similar house is 2 or in some cases the price, that means quite a jump in carrying costs.
4. So in addition to those priced out by the cost to purchase, there are others who are priced out by the carrying costs even if that can afford the purchase price.
3. A house that was one $250k and is now $500k has double the carrying costs, Same for house that was $500k and is now a million Or one that was $2.5 million and is now $5 and on and on.
2. As housing prices rise and reset to a new set point, carrying costs rise too.

26. On the other side, once these same workers start families, they may have relocation alternatives besides nearby suburbs — if they are able to take advantage of remote work and spread out to more affordable places.

25. This clustering with dispersion pattern being  accentuated by the life-cycle divide heightened by the pandemic. On one side, superstar cities and leading tech hubs continue to draw ambitious, educated younger people to their vibrant job markets and dating scenes.
24. You can think of it as dispersion within clustering or vice versa ...
23. Even as new hubs have entered the fray, the Bay Area and the Acela Corridor remain dominant. At the same time, dispersion is driven by the overall growth in the tech industry.
22. The big takeaways: Despite the ongoing shock waves of the Covid-19 pandemic, the geography of innovation in America looks like a slightly more stretched out version of what it did a decade ago.

19. And Austin & Miami are VERY DIFFERENT kinds of places. Austin is a long-established tech hub with long-established tied to Silicon Valley. Miami is more of a finance & real estate hub with ties to NYC. Both remain very much connected to these places.

18. But these amounts are a mere fraction of what leading hubs have attracted. They are significantly less than two older Frost Belt metros — Philadelphia, which drew in $7.7 billion, and Chicago, which drew in $7.2 billion in venture capital.
17. Much has been made of Austin and Miami as rising startup hubs. Both have certainly hauled in a lot of venture capital over the past year — $5 billion for Austin and $4.6 billion for Miami.

16. Those gains reflect the enormous overall rise of venture capital investment across the country - a huge wave that has enabled the development of larger and more viable startup ecosystems across a much broader range of locations.

15. This is not to say that the rest aren’t rising. A recent report by @SteveCase & his colleagues at Revolution found huge gains over the past decade in venture capital investment going to places like Nashville, Tampa, Salt Lake City, Dallas and more.

14. Taken together, just three mega-regions — the Bay Area; the Northeast corridor from Boston to Washington, D.C.; and Southern California — account for nearly 80% of all U.S. venture capital investment.

13. Indeed, even as remote work has talent its toll on the city, NYC remains the world’s dominant global city and continues to be a major draw for young, highly educated talent. A key reason why established tech firms like Google and Amazon are increasing their footprints there.

12. In 2021, the broader mega-region NY anchors — the Acela Corridor between Boston and Washington, D.C. — collectively received more than $100 billion, or roughly 30% of U.S. venture capital investment, about 85% as much as the Bay Area.

11. Next in line is New York, with more than $50 billion, roughly 16% of the total. Indeed, for all the talk of the rise of new startup hubs, New York saw the greatest increase in venture capital investment of any U.S. metro area between 2012 and 2021 — fully 7%.

10. That said, the Bay Area is a high amenity location that has had unmatched capacity to launch a series of leading-edge technology industries over the past few decades. It is unlikely to be dislodged as the dominant center for startups for some time.

9. with its rigid zoning and building codes inhibiting it from producing badly needed affordable housing and leaving it unable to adequately deal with rising urban disorder and homelessness etc etc ...

8. Where these earlier industrial clusters fell victim to technological shifts, labor-management conflicts, and institutional sclerosis associated with highly specialized work organization, the Bay Area today faces what some refer to as a governance crisis ...

7. The Bay Area does face real challenges. In some ways it looks like looks like a more specialized technology district, analogous in some ways to Pittsburgh’s steel and heavy industrial cluster, or Detroit’s automotive complex.

7. Just the San Francisco metro area alone hauled in $90 billion, the equivalent of nearly $20,000 in venture investment per resident. That’s a per capita rate almost three times that of Boston, 10 times more than Austin, and 20 times greater than Miami or New York.

6.  First things first: the San Francisco Bay Area remains the unquestioned leader in venture capital investment. The two metro areas that make up the Bay Area took in more than $120 billion in venture capital investment, more than a third (36%) of the U.S. total.

19. It will be interesting to see which of America's rising metros can effectively address these challenges.
18. This is why I increasingly like to say the New Urban Crisis has super quickly become an almost Everywhere Crisis.
17. These become real limits to growth. Perhaps the region can continue to "grow" based on imported capital. But these problems can only worsen.
16. Hard to see how these issues of housing affordability, inequity, transit all elements of the New Urban Crisis that have already hurt coastal superstar cities can be addressed.

15. Miami lacks the civic institutions like the RPA or Center for an Urban Future in NY, or SPUR in San Francisco, or universities in Boston - or even that exist in Austin, Denver, Nashville to focus and mobilize around the key challenges.

14. What is unique and exceptional about Miami is that with very few exceptions, there is a general unwillingness to even raise or discuss or have a conversation about such challenges. The default is a kind of extreme boosterism.

13. When outsiders from bigger, more affluent cities come in, they quickly housing prices up. If a metro like Miami with 5-6 million people cannot scale sufficiently to absorb this influx, it becomes that much harder in smaller metros.

12. Some call this "trickle down" migration, and it is. But it adds up to a rapidly metastasizing housing affordability crisis. I am getting an earful about lack of inventory, bidding wars, & unaffordability in just about every place I visit ...
11. And this is not just a Miami problem, it is impacting all the rising COVID big sort metros - Austin, Denver, Nashville, and ZoomTowns like Bozeman, NY's Hudson Valley, and on and on.
10. Then there is the traffic, the pressure on schools, the lack of slots at private schools ... I could go on.
9. And it's not just the poor and the essential workforce - think workforce housing - that are priced out, increasingly professionals/knowledge workers are priced out.

8. And local wages/ incomes are low, in what is still mainly a hospitality and tourism economy, among the lowest in the country. Although things are changing, the Miami economy still looks more like Las Vegas than NY or the Bay Area.

7. The fact of the matter is that a metro like Miami is not equipped to handle this kind of growth. The influx of out-of-towners - the global super-rich - puts extraordinary pressure on the housing market ... and more.

9. Yet with all those condos and apartments, it has not really taken the pressure of the single family home market.
8. Now here is where it gets interesting. Miami Beach is not your typical "suburb." It is dense overall, it is diverse,  it is mixed use, and it has pockets of extreme high-rise density.

7. Not only is the purchase price astronomical - a renovated dry lot house is now in the range of $5-8million or more. How many families are wealthy enough to carry that at say 4% a year with taxes and insurance.

10. "The shift is instead from the five largest cities in 1980, which fall from 32.3% to 20.0%."

9."tech clusters are also important for non-software patents, growing from 11.0% to 23.1% across the period. San Francisco is 11.1%. However, the share for the 270 MSAs grows slightly from 45.5% to 48.1%. ..."

8. The 6 "tech centers account for 45.4% of software patents after 2015, more than double their starting
share of 20.2%. San Francisco again features prominently with 25.8% of software patents filed
after 2015. This reallocation pulled from all regions."

7. "This reallocation is remarkable and has not been documented in prior work. Indeed, because the
reallocation is among big cities, this movement of well more than 10% of patents is almost completely orthogonal to the standard elasticity measured across the full city size."

6." The five largest population centers show the
largest drop, from 32.2% to 18.6%. By contrast, the aggregate decline for the other 270 cities,
from 45.5% to 41.0%, is much less. Non-urban areas also decline from 11.0% to 6.1%."

11. This shift also frees up key locational spaces, often at the very center of the metropolitan area for HOUSING, which given the housing affordability crisis faced by most advanced nations, is much more needed than locations for office work.

9. The shift to remote work - one of the biggest trends in the organization of work - accelerated by the pandemic allows for some reunification of the spaces for home & work, albeit *just* for very advantaged workers.

8. One of the big impactr of the industrial revolution was the separation of the home and work into separate spaces. And those spaces were stretched further & further apart on mass production of Fordist capitalism
7. The big trend here is to decentralization or disaggregation or spreading of work.  Co-working is also part of this.
6. We have also seen the rise of Central Social Districts & Central Recreational Districts ... in, around or adjacent to CBDs.
5. And urban CBDs were adding much more amenity and housing as many urbanists and downtown types have pointed out.

4. The CBD was spreading. In many cities, additional CBDs were cropping up in other locations. And not just in cities. Edge cities like Tysons Corner outside DC.  Poly-centrism has been on the rise, esp in younger SunBelt cities ...
3. The CBD was evolving in this direction before the pandemic.
2. This is yet another example of COVID-19 as accelerator (not disruptor).

15. Full story @CityLab with charts and tables here:
https://t.co/KNELnSaBdE
14. Vaccination is just the latest fissure that reflects and reinforces those ever deepening political, social and geographic divides
13. America remains a nation divided by class, and where different classes not only choose different political parties, but sort into and occupy different spaces.
12. Metro areas with higher vaccination rates are not just more likely to skew Democratic; they tend to be bigger and denser places, with higher incomes, and higher levels of education.

11. The rate of vaccination is also associated with the way we commute to work. A higher share of commuters who use public transit correlates to higher vaccination rates, while the share who drive to work alone is even more correlated to lower vaccination rates.
10. Vaccination rates track America's Density Divide. They are positively associated with the density and size of metro areas.
9. The correlation with the share of white residents is somewhat weaker, likely because significant shares of the white working class eschew vaccination.
8. Metros with a higher share of African Americans is associated with lower vaccination rates — a reflection of ongoing mistrust and likely inadequate outreach.
7. When it comes to race, higher vaccination rates are associated places that have greater proportions of Asian American and Hispanic residents.

6. Vaccination also varies by the kind of work that places specialize in — measured by broad categories of occupational class.  Vaccination is higher in metros with high concentrations of knowledge, professional and creative workers & lower in working-class metros.

5. Vaccination varies with the educational status of communities. Rates are significantly higher in places that have higher levels of educational attainment, measured as the share of adults who are college graduates.
4. Vaccination is associated with the wealth of places. The more affluent a metro area, the more likely it is to have a higher vaccination rate, by both median and average income.

2.  Much has been made of the political divide in vaccination. It's a super salient factor. But I wanted to look at other factors that might be associated in different rates of vaccination across metros. Thanks to @MarkMuro1 & @BrookingsMetro for data & @CharlottadcM for analysis

9. "this pattern of results is consistent with the idea that much economic activity in urban areas is concentrated n the service sector, and that access to surrounding locations to consume these services is an important determinant of workers’ choice of residence and workplace."

8. "we find a substantially larger contribution of travel access once we take into account consumption access
(56 percent compared to 37 percent), and a correspondingly smaller contribution from the residual
of residential amenities (44 percent compared to 63 percent)."

7. "Fourth, we show that trip chains are a relevant feature of the data, in which non-commuting trips occur along the journey between home and work, highlighting
the relevance of jointly modelling commuting and non-commuting trips."

6. " Second, we show that these non-commuting trips are closely related to the availability of nontraded services, which is consistent with our modelling of them as travel to consume non-traded services."

4. "We use the model to evaluate the role of consumption access in explaining the observed spatial variation in economic activity. We show that incorporating consumption access is quantitatively relevant for evaluating the observed impact of a new subway line."

3. "However, much of the travel that occurs within urban areas is related not to commuting but rather to the consumption of nontraded services, such as trips to restaurants, coffee shops and bars, shopping centers,
cultural venues, and other services."
2. "Traditional theories of cities emphasize production decisions and the costs of workers commuting between their workplace and residence."

16. Anyways, it's a great book. Do pick it up and give it a read. I learned a ton.

15. It reinforced something @iamstevenpedigo & I have been thinking about ... the pandemic may be accelerating a trends toward not just more gated communities, gate suburbs and gated cities but to a more Gated America ...

14. While the book is generally optimistic about cities, it makes the point that the pandemic is deepening not just socio-economic and racial divisions but spatial & geographic divides - both across & within cities.
13. Seems to me of the advanced nations, it’s US cities that are likely to be most impacted by the pandemic, largely because of the way they entered it.

12. As someone who splits his time between the US & Canada (Toronto), many if not most of the big  challenges they identify as facing cities - again, crime, disorder, schools  - seem to be much more salient to US cities than to cities in Canada or Europe.
11.  Those are big challenges here that were already observable back before the pandemic. I wrote about them for the NYT back in 2017. https://t.co/Nu81R8GGen

10. The book zeroes in on that fact that COVID is simply accelerating many of the key challenges to cities that were in place before it struck. Challenges like rising crime and disorder (& the perception of said) & the challenge of urban schools.
9. My own sense of this is that what we are seeing today  in terms of relocations & migrations associated with or accelerated by COVID can be seen as activated by such Olsonian factors.
8. And it picks up on and applies Mancur Olson's ideas about insiders, institutional sclerosis & rigidities as applying to cities today.
7. It makes an intriguing argument about the closing of the "metropolitan frontier" ...
6. The book picks up on discusses so many interesting ideas. I'll mention just two ...

5. For this pandemic & over the course of previous pandemics, it seems that plagues and infections disease  may pause but cannot overwhelm the connectivity that stands the heart of cities and urbanization.
4. The narrative arc of the book starts off sort of gloomy. But by the end it is rather optimistic. The book is a paean to the resilience & adaptive capabilities of great cities.

3.  For me the highlight of the book are the chapters which trace the history of pandemics & plagues & their impacts on cities and urbanization. It's clear Glaeser loves this material and that he has a penchant for economic history and it shines as a high point of the book.
2. First off, it's an extremely well-crafted book - a GREAT READ.

24. Ultimately, it is not so much place-based characteristics that mattered to the spread of COVID-19 but rather location, randomness, and bad luck.
23. The spread of COVID-19 has much more to do with factors which bear on diffusion, particularly location near hard-hit regions.

22. Perhaps the biggest takeaway from this study is that the geographic variation in COVID-19 and the vulnerability of certain places to it appear to have relatively little to do with their own characteristics.

21. Place-based factors explain only a small amount of the geographic variation of COVID-19 across Sweden—in fact, roughly only ten percent of the variation in COVID-19 cases across municipalities and just one precent across neighborhoods

20. When it comes to place-based factors, our findings suggest that the geographic variation of COVID-19 is only weakly related to socio-economic factors, and even fewer of these variables are significantly directly related to deaths from COVID-19.
19. The most significant place-based factor is the presence of high-risk nursing homes - not surprising given what we know about COVID in Sweden.

18. This likely reflects the fact that younger people were free to have contact with one another because Sweden did not impose any lockdowns, while older and more vulnerable people were more likely to isolate and physically distance.
17. The findings for age are also counter-intuitive. COVID-19 is negatively associated with the variables for age.

16. The variables for immigrants are positively and significantly associated with COVID-19. This may provide additional evidence for the association between COVID-19 & disadvantaged neighborhoods, as immigrants in Sweden are concentrated in less advantaged neighborhoods.
15. The findings for frontline workers also generate mixed results at the municipal level but are positively and significantly related to COVID-19 cases in the neighborhood-level analysis
14.  The factor for disadvantaged neighborhoods is modestly associated with COVID-19 cases in the neighborhood-level analysis.
13. These findings may reflect a more general result for city size, as bigger cities tend to be more affluent and educated but also more economically unequal.

12.  The variables for income and education are positively related with COVID-19 cases at the municipal level, which seems counter-intuitive.  However, as in other studies, the variable for income inequality is positively associated with COVID-19.
11. Our findings for the variables for socio-economic status are mixed & somewhat counter-intuitive.
9. We find that place-based factors played a far less significant role in the geographic incidence & spread of COVID-19 in Sweden.

8. Also significant is the timing of first infection.  Swedish cites & neighborhoods that were hit earlier by the virus seem to have been hit harder (a finding which is in line with previous research).

7. Proximity matters: The factor that explains the most variation in our models is proximity to other places with higher rates of infection. This factor explains more than half of the variation in COVID-19 across Swedish cities.
6. Overall, we find diffusion factors to be significantly more important than place-based factors in the spread of COVID-19 across Sweden.

5. Our research examines COVID infections & deaths across two geographic scales: all city-regions (municipalities) and neighborhoods in Sweden's 3 largest cities: Stockholm, Gothenburg and Malmö. The data cover the initial wave of COVID infections, February-August 2020.

4. Sweden is a useful case study to examine the interplay these factors because it did not impose mandatory lockdowns and because there was little or no geographic variation in the pandemic restrictions or policies.
3. Place-based factors  like density, socio-economic disparity, age levels, versus diffusion factors like proximity to harder hit areas which would be associated with the spread of COVID.
2. Our paper examines the role of 2 kinds of factors in the geography of COVID-19 in Sweden.

11. Short story: In our haste to extol the virtues of remote work (which I believe in) & to celebrate the demise of office-based control systems (which I am also on board with), we should be careful not to throw the proverbial "baby out with the bathwater."

9. To my mind it is a big mistake to think innovation & clustering do not matter & to be cheering on, or worse devising actual policies, that encourage widespread dispersal & decentralization, tho' the evolution of new regional hubs & clusters merits a look.
8. Still the main point is that clustering & density are key factors in innovation & national economic competitiveness.
7. Though others have pushed back on that and say a lot of startups are in around say downtown San Francisco.
6. I have elsewhere argued that that tends not to happen in central business districts but rather in innovation clusters like Silicon Valley or Lower Manhattan or Cambridge around MIT.  ...

5. Unless a whole lot of research by folks like Ed Glaeser & Enrico Morretti is very wrong, clustering, proximity, density - however you define what "cities do" is a main factor in innovation, creativity & productivity in knowledge-based capitalism.
4.BUT, even if in-office clustering, density & proximity do not matter. It is a big MISTAKE to think dispersed and distributed work will NOT effect innovation, creativity and productivity.
3. Though Thomas Allen's famous Allen Curve and Will Strange's work on vertical density merit close consideration. https://t.co/SDCfY1wpOr
2. My own hunch is that in-office work  does not matter significantly to this process.
1. We have reams of evidence that physical clustering of firms & people plays a huge role in innovation, creativity, productivity & economic growth.

13.  More than double the share of movers in dense urban areas (20%) said not needing to commute was a main factor in their move vs 10% of other movers.  40% of movers in dense urban areas expect to telecommute regularly vs. about a quarter of of other movers.
12. Study: "Movers in dense urban areas were not more likely than other movers to be motivated by either pandemic-related public health concerns or by a desire for a more comfortable home."
11. Moving/ Relocation: The big factor here, according to the study, is remote work.
10. That said, people say they are & will continue to walk and bike more. Nearly 15% plan to bike more & more than 20% say walking is one of the top 3 most enjoyable aspects of their new normal.

9. But it predicts a 40% decline in transit commute trips, post- versus pre-pandemic. Most of that shift (40%) entails a shift from transit to car commutes, with just 10% coming from other types of commutes like walking or biking.
8. The study projects at 15% decrease in car commuting ...
7.  Commuting: The shift to remote work has big implications for commuting, with the biggest impacts coming to transit.

5. There is a huge class divide in remote work: with the college educated and those making over $100k more than twice as likely to do so. Study: "Thus, these quality-of-life improvements will flow primarily to high-income, highly educated individuals."

4. Work: The share of workers who work remotely or "telecommute" a significant amount of time expected to increase to 26%. That's a big increase from pre-pandemic life, and in line with other estimates.

3.  The study looked at reported changes in the way people work, commute, shop, & how & where they live.  (One caveat which the study notes: surveys are contextual and temporally bounded so patterns & behaviors may change as we pass through the pandemic with time).

7. On a more minor and wonky note: the AmazonHQ2 bid  exposed the horrific inadequacy of Canadian locational data. And the inability to match it and compare it to US data which will handicap any future comparative location search efforts.
6. Far fewer US companies are looking to expand their footprint or to move across the border these days. A window of opportunity is lost.
5. I hate to say it but I think a lot of that advantage provided by the HQ2 bid has been near completely eroded by the combination of Covid, remote work, border closures and Covid restrictions.
4. That said, the bid made sense because it really did improve Toronto’s position as a destination for US and other global foreign direct investment in high technology.
3. Toronto had not a snowballs chance in hell of “winning” HQ2 which was going to either Greater DC or NYC from the very beginning.
2.  It included no “give-away” incentives & was completely transparent.
1   My 2 cents about this. Toronto put forward the best AmazonHQ2 bid of any city.

9. Could urban economics be an example for increasing the relevance of economics profession & social sciences more broadly, perhaps ...?

8. But when you add it all up & take it as a whole, the contributions - both academic & in the popular literature - by urban economists have literally helped to transformed the way we understand cities & places ...
7. Sure there is too much emphasis on formal models, cute technique, clean data sets in this published research. Sure it could be even more relevant ...
6. And across the board my field of cities & urbanism is incalculably better for the contributions coming from urban economics. And they are growing. There is lots more to come.

5. Two decades or so ago, let's say during the 1990s, urban economists made up maybe 10-20% of what I read & was influenced by. Today, urban economists probably make up 80-90% of what I read & influenced by.

4. Now add to that the contributions of a range of younger academically trained urban economists like @JedKolko & @issiromem & many others - whose by lines and data appear in the @nytimes & many other places.
3. The contributions of Glaeser, Morretti, Gyourko - & many, many, many - more have literally transformed the field, making it more focussed, more methodologically sophisticated & YES, more relevant.

2.  I have to admit (grudgingly as a non-economist) that when I look at contributions to the broad field of cities & urbanism, the contributions of urban economists (both inside & outside academic institutions) have grown tremendously in volume & importance.

1. I very much agree with @tylercowen that economics (& lots of social science) more broadly has become overly concerned with "perfect" technique (& data) & less relevant to the real world. That said ...

7.  Put Austin & Miami together, and they account for roughly $1.3b in VC investment of just under 2%.
6. Miami is currently in 15th place with just under $500m or 0.7%.
5. Rounding out the top 10 are: Chicago ($2b, 2.9%), Philadelphia ($1.8b, 2.6%), Seattle ($1.6b, 2.3%), DC ($1.3b, 1.9%), Denver ($1.2b, 1.7%), & Austin $800m, 1.2%).
4. So together the 4 leading tech hubs - the Bay Area, NY, Boston & LA - account for almost three-quarters of all US VC investment. That's pretty winner-take-all.

3. There are 3 other leading tech hubs - NY, Boston-Cambridge & Los Angeles.  NY w/ $10.5 b or 15.2%, Boston w/ $7.9 b or 11.4%, & LA w/ $6.7 b or 9.7%. Together these 3 hubs have a share roughly equivalent to the Bay Area.
2. Little evidence of any "tech-odus" from the San Francisco Bay Area. The Bay Area remains far & away the leader with $25.3 billion in VC investment or 36.7% of the total.

15. And these are moves that are driven by class position & demography, with older, more affluent people moving toward warmer, less dense, less stringent locations & younger, highly educated people continuing to head to superstar cities.
14. I think this, and not density per se, lies behind these moves.

13. What I think is driving these moves is a preference for "normalcy", the pursuit of personal freedom & day to day liberty, & the ability to live one's life & family they way you choose, less subject to government mandates.
12. This is coupled with fear of an ongoing pandemic, & a preference not simply for less density but for warmer climates & for more outdoor space - both for conducting business & outdoor socializing.

11. This is even more the case with entrepreneurs, VCs, investment & real estate types who thrive on risk. They prefer & are voting with their feet for less risk-averse, less stringent, more open places.

10. These households have more ability to move & less tolerance for restrictions. They feel they can manage risk on their own without government restrictions. They also prefer environments where in-person schooling is more likely.

9. My take on this is that the overall driver in these migrations is flight from restrictions. Higher income households are moving from more restrictive places (which also happen to be larger, denser & bluer) to less restrictive places.

8. "larger households with kids will have some different motivations for moving than households without kids. For instance, 5% of COVID-19 influenced moves cited having access to in-person learning as an important factor in their decision."
7.  "These changes in time-use will increase the value of a good climate, access to outdoor recreation, and also the amount of space in one's home. "

6. "the high costs of indoor socialization during the pandemic has led to a significant change in how people spend their time: an increase in outdoor activities and
more time spent in one's own home versus in common areas indoors ..."
5. "Households are moving to areas with fewer cases, less restrictions, lower density, and lower rent relatively more."

4. "We find households are moving away relatively more from areas with greater remote work jobs, more stringent pandemic-related restrictions, and areas with higher rent-levels during the pandemic compared to normal times."

3. "We find very different patterns across higher-income and lower-income migrants with higher income households moving out of more populous cities at greater rates, and moving more for lifestyle reasons and much less for work-related reasons compared to the pre-pandemic period."

2. "We find 10-20% of moves between April 2020-February 2021 were influenced by COVID-19, with a significant shift in migration towards smaller cities, lower cost of living locations, and locations with fewer
pandemic-related restrictions."

1. This is a very important paper which traces long distances moves for different classes of people. The big conclusion is that the moves of more affluent higher income people are away from more restrictive or stringent place to less restrictive ones.

Positive correlation with commuters who bike to work (.51) Negative correlation with share  of commuters who drive to work by car (-.50).

Knowledge, professional and creative jobs (.37) 
College grads (.50)
High-tech industry (.34) 
Innovation (patents, .42)
7. Remote work was modestly correlated with population size (.22) and density (.30).

24. And that would be squarely in line with the evolution of advance capitalism which is toward ever more distributed & unequal geographies ...
23. One possible big implication of the pandemic then is an even more finely grained, uneven and segmented spatial division of labor ...

22. From an economic development perspective we may see a growing disjuncture or disconnect from "HQ places" where founders live & work - Miami Beach, Malibu, the Hamptons (for example), & talent clusters where professional & knowledge workers live & work.
21. But there is less reason for talent to necessarily cluster in those locations. A Miami or Bozeman startup for example can draw off talent clusters across the nation ... or world.
20. This means that it may well be easier for founders CEOs to build companies from lifestyle locations like Miami or Park City or Bozeman (i could go on).
19. I expect this hub and spoke pattern to grow, and for corporate location to become somewhat disconnected from talent location.
18. Despite declines, there remains a critical mass in the Bay Area & NY. But other talent clusters are clearly emerging & not just in the Austins of the world, but in smaller places ...
17. This can be seen concretely by looking at the location of company employees.  From what I am seeing they are not spread out evenly, but clustered in a fairly narrow range of locations.
16. Older people with families will spread out in search of lower costs & certain kinds of amenity ...
15. Young folks will continue to be drawn to cities for a combination of thick labor and more so mating markets ...
14. There is a demographic and lifestyle divide in such talent clustering.
14. Simply put, the pandemic & the rise of remote technologies has shifted the balance of clustering from firms to PEOPLE.

13. The pattern of talent clustering is a product of the external human capital economies identified as a main driver of innovation and economic growth by Jane Jacobs & later formalized by Robert Lucas, and shown empirically in studies by Ed Glaeser & others.
12. But talent is not and will not spread out in a flat world pattern. Talent continues to cluster in select locations.
11. All of this is "good news" for rise of the rest lifestyle locations like Miami or Park City - a range of high amenity locations where founders/ CEOs may want to live.
10.  And we know from a large literature that HQs tend to locate where founders/CEOs want to live.
9. This creates greater possibility for companies to locate their HQ (main base location) in a more diverse array of locations.
8. @IanHathaway finds an increase in "remote" investments by venture capitalists including those in the Bay Area.
6. But what we seem to be seeing is continued & perhaps enhanced talent clustering, even as those talent clusters spread out.
5.  What we seem to be seeing is a shift from corporate or industry clustering to talent clusters. It is less necessary for businesses to cluster.
4.  But it does appear that both previous technologies & particularly the rise of remote work-enabling technology IS shifting the nature and type of clustering.
3. Clustering has only become stronger in the wake of previous advances in "distance enhancing" technology. Not so obvious reasons why this time should be different.
2.  There is no doubt in my mind that clustering will remain critical to both innovation & productivity growth, even in the wake of COVID-19 and the rise of remote work.
